factoid: The speaker said "Gott, wie naiv!" angrily.
The speaker went a few steps after speaking.
The speaker said "Good God, what simplicity!".
Nesvítski laughed while throwing his arms round Prince Andrew.
Nesvítski threw his arms round Prince Andrew.
Bolkónski turned still paler.
Bolkónski pushed Nesvítski away with an angry look.
Bolkónski turned to Zherkóv.
The appearance of Mack aroused nervous irritation.
The news of Mack's defeat aroused nervous irritation.
The thought of what lay before the Russian army aroused nervous irritation.
The nervous irritation found vent in anger at Zherkóv’s untimely jest.
Bolkónski said "If you, sir, choose to make a buffoon of yourself...".
Bolkónski said "I can’t prevent your doing so.".
Bolkónski warned that if you dare to play the fool in his presence, he will teach you to behave yourself.
Nesvítski and Zherkóv were surprised by Bolkónski's outburst.
Nesvítski gazed at Bolkónski silently with wide-open eyes.
Zherkóv gazed at Bolkónski silently with wide-open eyes.
Zherkóv said "What's the matter? I only congratulated them.".
Bolkónski cried "I am not jesting with you; please be silent!".
Bolkónski took Nesvítski’s arm.
Bolkónski left Zherkóv.
Zherkóv did not know what to say.
Nesvítski said "Come, what's the matter, old fellow?" while trying to soothe Bolkónski.
Prince Andrew exclaimed "What's the matter?" while standing still in excitement.

Prince Andrew said "Don’t you understand that either we are officers serving our Tsar and our country, rejoicing in the successes and grieving at the misfortunes of our common cause, or we are merely lackeys who care nothing for their master’s business.".
Prince Andrew said "Quarante mille hommes massacrés et l’armée de nos alliés détruite, et vous trouvez là le mot pour rire.".
Prince Andrew said "C’est bien pour un garçon de rien comme cet individu dont vous avez fait un ami, mais pas pour vous, pas pour vous.".
Prince Andrew added in Russian, with a French accent, "Only a hobbledehoy could amuse himself in this way.".
Prince Andrew waited a moment to see whether the cornet would answer.
Prince Andrew turned and went out of the corridor.
The Pávlograd Hussars were stationed two miles from Braunau.
Nicholas Rostóv served as a cadet in a squadron quartered in Salzeneck.
Denísov was the squadron commander.
Denísov was known throughout the cavalry division as Váska Denísov.
The best quarters in Salzeneck were assigned to Denísov.
Nicholas Rostóv had lived with Denísov since he had overtaken the regiment in Poland.
On October 11, the camp life of the squadron officers was proceeding as usual.
On October 11, news of Mack’s defeat was reported at headquarters.
Denísov had been losing at cards all night.
Denísov had not yet come home when Nicholas Rostóv rode back early in the morning.
Nicholas Rostóv rode back early in the morning from a foraging expedition.
Nicholas Rostóv rode up to the porch in his cadet uniform.
Nicholas Rostóv swung his leg over the saddle with a supple youthful movement.
Nicholas Rostóv stood for a moment in the stirrup as if loathe to part from his horse.
Nicholas Rostóv sprang down and called to his orderly.
Nicholas Rostóv said "Ah, Bondarénko, dear friend!" to Bondarénko.
Nicholas Rostóv told Bondarénko to walk him up and down.
Nicholas Rostóv was showing gay brotherly cordiality.
Bondarénko answered "Yes, your excellency," gaily, tossing his head.
Bondarénko said "Mind, walk him up and down well!".
Another hussar rushed toward the horse.
Bondarénko had thrown the reins of the snaffle bridle over the horse’s head.
Nicholas Rostóv was liberal with his tips.
Serving Nicholas Rostóv paid off.
Nicholas Rostóv patted the horse’s neck.
Nicholas Rostóv patted the horse’s flank.
Nicholas Rostóv lingered for a moment.
